title: Posterior Reversible Encephalopathy Syndrome (PRES)
scope: ** Diagnosis and management of posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) in adults across all care settings. Covers hypertensive emergency management, seizure treatment, identification and removal of causative agents (immunosuppressants, chemotherapy), eclampsia-specific management, MRI interpretation, hemorrhagic PRES complications, and recovery monitoring. Excludes pediatric PRES, chronic hypertensive encephalopathy without neuroimaging features, and isolated eclampsia management without PRES features (see obstetric protocols).

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain without contrast (CPT 70551) with FLAIR, DWI, ADC, SWI/GRE sequences

Essential/First-line.target: Bilateral symmetric vasogenic edema predominantly in posterior parietal-occipital regions on FLAIR; DWI normal or mildly restricted; ADC elevated (confirms vasogenic, not cytotoxic edema); SWI/GRE for hemorrhagic component
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Pacemaker/defibrillator (non-MRI conditional); hemodynamic instability (stabilize BP first)

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology / Neurocritical care for PRES diagnosis confirmation, seizure management, and neuroimaging interpretation
Nephrology for acute kidney injury management, dialysis evaluation, and hypertensive nephropathy assessment
Obstetrics/Maternal-Fetal Medicine STAT if eclampsia suspected for delivery planning and magnesium management
Transplant team (solid organ or bone marrow) for immunosuppressant adjustment and alternative regimen selection
Hematology if TTP/HUS suspected (schistocytes, thrombocytopenia, renal failure) for plasma exchange evaluation
Oncology for chemotherapy-associated PRES to discuss offending agent discontinuation and alternative regimen
Cardiology for hypertensive cardiomyopathy evaluation, stress cardiomyopathy management, or arrhythmia assessment
Ophthalmology for acute visual changes, cortical blindness evaluation, papilledema assessment, and hypertensive retinopathy grading
Physical therapy for early mobilization and strength assessment once seizures controlled and BP stable
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, cognitive rehabilitation, and visual field adaptation
Speech-language pathology for dysphagia screening before PO intake and cognitive-communication assessment
Social work for discharge planning, medication access, transplant support, and family counseling
Pharmacy for medication reconciliation, immunosuppressant level optimization, and antihypertensive titration guidance

Patient / Family Instructions.item: PRES is typically reversible with prompt treatment; most patients recover fully with aggressive BP control and removal of the offending cause
Call 911 immediately if new or worsening headache, seizure activity, vision changes, confusion, or difficulty speaking (may indicate PRES recurrence or complication)
Take all blood pressure medications as prescribed; do NOT skip doses or stop medications without physician guidance as this can trigger recurrence
Monitor blood pressure at home daily; keep a BP log; report readings consistently above 140/90 to your physician
If you had seizures with PRES, do NOT drive until cleared by neurology (typically after imaging resolution and seizure-free period per state law)
If PRES was caused by an immunosuppressant medication, do NOT resume the medication without explicit transplant team or oncology approval
Visual changes from PRES usually improve over days to weeks; report any persistent vision problems at follow-up
Report any new headaches, confusion, or seizures immediately as these may indicate incomplete resolution or recurrence
Pregnancy counseling: if eclampsia-related PRES, discuss future pregnancy risks and preeclampsia prevention (low-dose aspirin prophylaxis) with OB

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Blood pressure target <130/80 mmHg long-term to prevent PRES recurrence (most important modifiable risk factor)
Low-sodium diet (DASH diet: <2300 mg sodium/day, ideally <1500 mg) to improve blood pressure control
Smoking cessation to reduce vascular risk and improve blood pressure control
Alcohol limitation (maximum 1 drink/day for women, 2 for men) as excess alcohol worsens hypertension
Regular aerobic exercise (150 min/week moderate intensity) after medical clearance to improve cardiovascular health and BP
Weight management (target BMI <30) as obesity independently worsens hypertension and cardiovascular risk
Medication adherence for all chronic medications including antihypertensives and immunosuppressants
Stress management and adequate sleep (7-8 hours nightly) as contributors to blood pressure control
For transplant patients: strict adherence to immunosuppressant schedule and regular drug level monitoring to prevent toxicity
Preeclampsia prevention in future pregnancies: low-dose aspirin (81-162 mg daily starting at 12-16 weeks gestation) for women with eclampsia history

differential.features: Focal neurological deficit corresponding to vascular territory; DWI restriction on MRI; absence of bilateral posterior edema

differential.features: Headache, seizures, focal deficits; hemorrhagic venous infarct; does not respect arterial territories; postpartum
differential.tests: MRV or CT venography (thrombosed sinus); D-dimer; PRES has bilateral posterior edema without sinus thrombosis

differential.features: Multifocal lesions; vessel wall enhancement; progressive course; may have systemic vasculitis features
differential.tests: DSA (irregular segmental narrowing); vessel wall MRI; CSF (pleocytosis, elevated protein); biopsy

differential.features: Fever; temporal lobe involvement (mesial temporal, insular cortex); CSF pleocytosis; rapid deterioration
differential.tests: MRI (temporal lobe edema/hemorrhage); CSF HSV PCR; PRES involves parietal-occipital predominantly

differential.features: Thunderclap headache; segmental vasoconstriction on CTA/DSA; resolves in 3 months; may coexist with PRES

differential.tests: MRI (multifocal white matter lesions with enhancement; involves corpus callosum); CSF (pleocytosis)

differential.features: Thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, neurological symptoms, renal dysfunction, fever
differential.tests: ADAMTS13 activity (<10%); schistocytes; TTP can coexist with PRES

differential.features: Rapid sodium correction; central pontine or extrapontine myelinolysis; may occur in hyponatremia correction
differential.tests: MRI (central pons T2/FLAIR hyperintensity); sodium correction history; location differs from PRES

differential.features: Acute onset; brainstem/cerebellar signs; unilateral or asymmetric; DWI restriction
differential.tests: MRI DWI (restricted diffusion in PCA territory); CTA (basilar/PCA occlusion); PRES is bilateral and vasogenic

evidence.recommendation: PRES is characterized by vasogenic edema predominantly in posterior cerebral regions, diagnosed by MRI FLAIR and DWI/ADC
evidence.source: [Fugate & Rabinstein. NEJM 2015](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26466778/) -- Comprehensive review of PRES

evidence.recommendation: Blood pressure reduction should target 25% MAP reduction in first hour with gradual lowering to 160/100 over next 2-6 hours
evidence.source: AHA/ACC 2017 Hypertension Guidelines; [Whelton et al. JACC 2018](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29146535/)

evidence.recommendation: Nicardipine IV is preferred first-line agent for hypertensive emergency management in PRES
evidence.source: [Peacock et al. J Clin Hypertens 2011](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21545393/); AHA/ACC Guidelines

evidence.recommendation: Magnesium sulfate is superior to phenytoin and diazepam for prevention of recurrent eclamptic seizures
evidence.source: [Eclampsia Trial Collaborative Group. Lancet 1995](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7776345/); [Magpie Trial. Lancet 2002](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12076174/)

evidence.recommendation: Calcineurin inhibitor (tacrolimus, cyclosporine) toxicity is a leading cause of PRES in transplant patients; drug should be held or dose reduced
DWI/ADC mapping distinguishes vasogenic edema (PRES) from cytotoxic edema (infarction); ADC values are elevated in vasogenic edema
PRES can occur at normal or mildly elevated blood pressures, particularly in immunosuppressed and eclamptic patients
Hemorrhagic PRES occurs in 15-25% of cases and is associated with worse outcomes; anticoagulation should be avoided
PRES typically resolves within 2 weeks with appropriate treatment; persistent imaging abnormalities warrant reconsideration of diagnosis
evidence.source: [Fugate et al. Mayo Clin Proc 2010](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20435835/) -- 120-patient case series

evidence.recommendation: Levetiracetam is preferred ASM for PRES-associated seizures due to lack of hepatic metabolism and drug interactions
evidence.source: Expert consensus; favorable pharmacokinetic profile in transplant and chemotherapy populations

evidence.recommendation: VEGF inhibitors (bevacizumab, sunitinib) cause PRES through endothelial dysfunction; hold and rechallenge cautiously if needed
Low-dose aspirin (81-162 mg daily from 12-16 weeks) reduces preeclampsia risk by 17% in high-risk pregnancies
RCVS and PRES may coexist and share pathophysiological mechanisms involving endothelial dysfunction
Seizure prophylaxis duration after PRES-associated seizures is typically 3-6 months with taper if imaging normalized and EEG normal
evidence.source: Expert consensus; no randomized trial data on optimal duration

evidence.recommendation: Non-convulsive status epilepticus occurs in up to 15% of PRES patients with altered consciousness; continuous EEG monitoring recommended
Posterior fossa involvement in PRES (brainstem, cerebellum) carries risk of obstructive hydrocephalus and brainstem herniation

monitoring.item: Blood pressure (arterial line in ICU, cuff elsewhere)
monitoring.frequency: q5min during acute IV titration; q15min x 6h; q1h x 24h; then q4h
monitoring.action: Titrate IV antihypertensives; if SBP <120 reduce drip rate; reassess if >180 despite max dosing

monitoring.item: Neurological exam (GCS, pupils, motor, speech, vision)
monitoring.frequency: q1h x 24h; then q2h x 24h; then q4h
monitoring.action: If declining: STAT CT; reassess BP; check for hemorrhagic conversion; assess for NCSE; neurosurgery if hemorrhagic

monitoring.frequency: Continuous if on cEEG; clinical observation q1h
monitoring.action: Load additional ASM; upgrade to cEEG if subclinical seizures suspected; escalate to RSE protocol if refractory

monitoring.item: Visual acuity and visual field assessment
monitoring.frequency: q8h during acute phase; daily; then at follow-up
monitoring.action: If worsening: repeat MRI; ophthalmology consultation; reassess BP control

monitoring.item: Serum magnesium (if on Mg sulfate drip)
monitoring.action: If >8: hold infusion, check DTRs/respiratory rate; if <4: increase rate; calcium gluconate 1 g IV for toxicity

monitoring.item: Deep tendon reflexes (if on Mg sulfate)
monitoring.action: Loss of DTRs = magnesium toxicity approaching; hold infusion; check level; calcium gluconate 1 g IV at bedside
Adjust medications for renal function; nephrology consult if worsening; dialysis if severe AKI

monitoring.frequency: q24h until stable; then per transplant protocol
monitoring.action: Coordinate with transplant team; do not increase to target levels until PRES resolved; monitor for rejection
Insulin drip or sliding scale adjustment; avoid hypoglycemia (<70)
Antipyretics; cooling if refractory; infection workup if persistent fever

monitoring.frequency: At 2-4 weeks; repeat at 3 months if abnormalities persist
monitoring.action: If persistent: reconsider diagnosis; assess for ongoing cause; consider cerebral biopsy if atypical
Volume assessment; adjust fluids; consider nephrology if oliguria; dialysis for anuria

disposition.criteria: BP controlled on oral medications; seizure-free >24h on oral ASMs; neurological exam at or near baseline; improving vision; follow-up MRI and neurology scheduled within 2-4 weeks; underlying cause identified and addressed; reliable social support and medication access
Mild PRES with BP controlled on IV medications with planned oral transition; seizures controlled; GCS 14-15; stable imaging without hemorrhage; oral intake tolerated; no ICU-level monitoring needs

Severe hypertensive emergency requiring arterial line and IV antihypertensive titration; hemorrhagic PRES; recurrent seizures or status epilepticus; GCS <13 or declining; respiratory compromise requiring intubation; eclampsia requiring magnesium drip with continuous monitoring; posterior fossa edema with brainstem compression risk

disposition.disposition: Transfer to higher level of care
disposition.criteria: Need for neurocritical care not available at current facility; need for emergent delivery (eclampsia) with inadequate OB/NICU support; need for neurosurgery (hemorrhagic PRES with mass effect); need for dialysis not available

Neurology in 2-4 weeks for clinical assessment and follow-up MRI review; ophthalmology if persistent visual symptoms; nephrology for ongoing renal issues; transplant clinic within 1-2 weeks if immunosuppressant adjustment made; OB for postpartum eclampsia follow-up; PCP for long-term BP management
